Felix Brandt Felix Fischer

Motivation
I Nash equilibrium: strategy profile that does not allow beneficial unilateral deviation
I Guaranteed to exist in finite games, but usually not unique I Equilibrium refinements that single out particularly reasonable
equilibria (see, e.g., van Damme 1983) I Quasi-strict equilibrium (Harsanyi, 1973): every best response
played with positive probability I Isolated q.s.e. are essential, strongly stable, regular, proper, and
strictly perfect I Satisfy Cubitt & Sugden (1994) axioms, existence of q.s.e.
justifies assumption of common knowledge of rationality

Some Facts about Quasi-Strict Equilibria
I Guaranteed to exist in bimatrix games (Norde, 1999) and generic n-player games (Harsanyi, 1973)
I But not in three-player games, we will see an example later (others by van Damme, 1983; Kojima et al., 1984; Cubitt & Sugden, 1994; Brandt et al., 2007)
I PPAD-hard in bimatrix games (trivial) I Membership in PPAD not obvious (Brouwer fixed point of a
mapping that is complicated to construct) I We will see it is likely harder in three-player games

Anonymous and Symmetric Games
I Anonymous game: payoff depends on own action and number of other players playing each of the different actions (but not their identities)
I Symmetric game: anonymous plus identical payoff functions for all players

NP-Hardness in Multi-Player Games
I Theorem: Deciding whether a three-player game has a quasi-strict equilibrium is NP-complete
I Proof sketch: I Reduction from CLIQUE, inspired by McLennan &
Tourky (2005) I Actions of players 1 and 2 correspond to vertices of a graph I Player 1 gets more payoff for vertices connected by an edge I Player 2 plays the same actions as player 1 in every
equilibrium (imitation game) I Player 3 has two actions, with payoff the same as player 1 or
depending on the desired clique size, respectively

Conclusion
I Quasi-strict equilibrium: Nash equilibrium where every best response is played with positive probability
I Main results: I Every symmetric game with two actions has a quasi-strict
equilibrium I Deciding existence in three-player games is NP-complete
(so the search problem is NP-hard under Turing reductions) I Open Problems:
I Complexity of the search problem in bimatrix games I Existence in larger classes of multi-player games (e.g.,
symmetric games with more than two actions)
